summary: HTLV-1 is the etiologic agent of adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) and HTLV-1-associated myelopathy/tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP) in infected individuals. HTLV-1 is the etiologic agent of adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATLL) and HTLV-1-associated myelopathy/tropical spastic parapare HTLV-1 Tax acts to transactivate the viral long terminal repeat (LTR) through tax-responsive elements (TREs) in the U3 region. this occurs through transcriptional induction of TREs, posttranslational modifications of TRE-binding factors, and binding with transcription factors. tax is known to interact with the transcription factors CREB, serum-responsive factor, and NF-B. tax activates HTLV-1 transcription through CREB and three CRE enhancer sequences on the LTR. tax also interacts with CBP/p300, which is involved in the formation of the preinitiation complex and the p300/CBP-associated factor, P/CAF. tax is heavily involved in direct interactions with critical cellular proteins that control not only viral gene expression but also cellular genes involved in tumor formation. HTLV-1 infection in the presence of Tax significantly downregulates Drosha protein expression. the changes in cellular miRNA expression in HTLV-1 infected cells can be mimicked in uninfected cells. retroviruses have been shown to control the cellular RNAi pathway. HTLV-1 infection results in a dramatic up (i.e. miR-130b, miR-18a, miR-20b) and downregulation of many host cellular miRNAs. the modulation of these host miRNAs has an effect on the expression of cellular proteins such as p300, NF-B, and BRM. tax would decrease Drosha levels, resulting in downregulation of miRNAs. cellular miRNAs, such as Let-7i, miR-199a-3p, and miR-132, are downregulated after infection. a set of cellular miRNAs are known to be recruited and utilized by the HTLV-1 promoter. densitometry counts of western blots for each indicated protein normalized to -Actin, plotted as a percent change (measured as arbitrary counts) between antagomiR treated cells and 293T cells alone. HTLV-1 is an oncogenic retrovirus which targets and manipulates common cellular tumor suppressors and signaling pathways in order to establish and maintain a productive infection. all DNA tumor viruses encode viral miRNAs which modulate tumorigenesis, thus indicating that the cellular RNAi pathway is important for viral pathogenesis and control. we have demonstrated that Drosha is downregulated in HTLV-1 infected cell lines. we have also shown that Dicer is downregulated in HTLV-1 infected cell lines only. this suggests that this loss of Dicer could be due to a cell line specific phenomenon. the N-terminus of Tax is most commonly known for the CREB (cAMP-responsive element-binding)-transactivation domain. the transcription factors p300/CBP, and p/CAF (p300/CBP-associated factor) bind and promote viral transcription from the LTR. this interaction is not seen when a cell is expressing the tax mutant, ACH.M22. three large studies have examined the dysregulation of cellular miRNAs in both HTLV-1 infected cell lines and ATLL samples. these studies provide a large pool of upregulated and downregulated cellular miRNAs from which to pull functional data in the context of HTLV-1 infection. endogenous Drosha is less functional and not as efficient in processing miRNAs in the presence of tax. HTLV-1 infection downregulates a particular miRNA which targets a cellular protein necessary for tax transactivation. if HTLV-1 downregulates a particular miRNA, we could mimic this interaction by introducing an antagomiR into uninfected cells. miR-199a-3p has been shown to regulate IKK- to affect NF-B activity. antagomiRs mimic the cellular protein expression seen in tax-expressing cells. tax plays a major role in the activation of cellular NF-B.
